message.content:
Analyze the cephalometric analysis field (orthodontic/maxillofacial) to understand how side profile landmark detection is typically done in professional settings.

Research:
1. What landmarks are critical for cephalometric analysis
2. How the Frankfort Horizontal Plane is typically measured
3. What commercial or open-source tools exist for cephalometric tracing
4. Any papers or references to automated cephalometric analysis

Look for any web-based cephalometric analysis tools that we could learn from. Thoroughness: very thorough

content.text: I'll conduct a thorough research into cephalometric analysis in orthodontics and maxillofacial surgery, focusing on side profile landmark detection and related tools.

input.query: cephalometric analysis landmarks orthodontic side profile 2025
Frankfort Horizontal Plane measurement orthodontics cephalometry
automated cephalometric tracing software open source
machine learning deep learning cephalometric landmark detection

Based on my search, here are the results for automated cephalometric tracing software that is open source:

## Open Source Options

### 1. **Cephalopoint**
Cephalopoint is an open source software code programmed on Octave; each code applied vector and matrix operations to measure the Cephalometric traces according to Downs and Steiner's Analysis.(no content)Much commercial software is created, but its high cost is unaffordable for some undergraduate students or low-income medical institutions; the software was designed to offer a free alternative that applies vector algebra to perform accurate and precise cephalometric analysis.(no content)Cephalopoint application showed accuracy in the results very close to manually; the time expended was a third part of the manual technique.

### 2. **AI-based Open-Source Software for Limited FOV Radiographs**
To enhance the diagnostic processes in dentistry, an open-source software that utilises AI to improve the extraction of cephalometric values from limited field of view (FOV) images was created.(no content)Evaluation of the software showed that it was effective in accurately predicting key cephalometric measurements, suggesting that it could be a reliable tool for clinical use.

### 3. **GitHub - Cephalometric Analysis Web Application**
Using this little web application you can upload a lateral cephalogram and do a computer assisted cephalometric analysis for orthodontic diagnostic use. This is available at github.com/alexcorvi/cephalometric.

## Commercial Alternatives (for reference)
There are several commercial alternatives to perform the technique; among them, we can mention Quick Ceph, Dolphin, Nemoceph, Vistadent, TraceCeph, CephX, and Facad.(no content)More than 350 orthodontic applications are currently available, many of which are open source.

## AI-Based Automated Tracing Technology
Cephalometric tracing is based on artificial intelligence, using a deep convolutional neural network (CNN) for landmark detection, followed by an active shape model (ASM) for adjusting the position of the whole structure.

PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/792431/"},{"title":"Validating the 3D and 2D Mandibular Plane to the Frankfort ...","url":"https://www.tjo.org.tw/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1022&context=tjo"},{"title":"Effects of Changes in the Frankfort Horizontal Plane Definition on the Three-Dimensional Cephalometric Evaluation of Symmetry","url":"https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/10/22/7956"},{"title":"Influence of different setups of the Frankfort horizontal plane on 3-dimensional cephalometric measurements - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28760286/"},{"title":"Influence of different setups of the Frankfort horizontal plane on 3-dimensional cephalometric measurements - ScienceDirect","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0889540617303566"},{"title":"Three-dimensional Frankfort horizontal plane for 3D cephalometry: a comparative assessment of conventional versus novel landmarks and horizontal ...","url":"https://academic.oup.com/ejo/article/40/3/239/4107607"},{"title":"New perspectives on orientation and their benefits to clinical orthodontics - part I - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1059336/?dopt=Abstract"},{"title":"Three-dimensional Frankfort horizontal plane for 3D cephalometry: a comparative assessment of conventional versus novel landmarks and horizontal planes - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29016738/"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the Frankfort Horizontal Plane in orthodontics and cephalometry:

## Frankfort Horizontal Plane in Orthodontics and Cephalometry

### Definition
The Frankfort horizontal (FH) is a plane that intersects both porions and the left orbitale.(no content)The plane formed by the intersection of bilateral porions (PoR and PoL) and left orbitale (OrL) is conventionally defined as the Frankfort horizontal (FH) plane.

### Historical Background
The Frankfort Craniometric Agreement of August 1882 is considered a landmark development in anthropometrics.(no content)It developed a horizontal plane of reference, referred to as the Frankfort horizontal (FH) plane. The FH plane or the auriculo-orbital plane closely represents the natural head position. Thus, it was rapidly adapted for patient orientation in cephalometric imaging.

### Clinical Importance
Cephalometric measurement values are used by surgeons and orthodontists for diagnosis, treatment planning, and treatment evaluation of orthodontic and orthognathic surgery patients. The greater the accuracy of these values, the lower the probability of disparate or erroneous clinical outcomes.(no content)The major functions of cephalometrics were pointed out to be its use for description or classification of the face together with the malocclusion and for superimpositioning for longitudinal comparison.(no content)The statistical findings via a computer pointed to the use of the Frankfort plane as the most desirable basic reference for descriptive reasons.

### Frankfort Mandibular Plane Angle (FMA)
An FMA of 25 +/- 5 degrees is within normal range. A high-angle patient has an FMA of 30 degrees or more, and a low-angle patient has an FMA of 20 degrees or less.

### 3D Cephalometry Considerations
The reliability of 3D cephalometric landmarking and Frankfort Horizontal plane construction is a recurrent clinical issue in orthodontics and orthognathic surgery planning.(no content)Other combinations of points have also been used to define this plane in 3-dimensional cephalometry.(no content)This investigation showed that significant and undesirable measurement differences can be produced by varying the definition of the FH plane.(no content)The FH plane definition can significantly influence the interpretation of cephalometric findings. Future studies should focus on standardization to improve the reliability and reproducibility of 3D cephalometry.

### Landmark Reliability
Overall, "dental" and "foraminal" landmarks were more reliable than the "conventional" landmarks. Despite the poor reliability of the landmarks orbitale and porion, the construction of the conventional FH plane provided a reliable horizontal reference for 3D craniofacial CT scan reorientation.

Links: [{"title":"Deep learning for cephalometric landmark detection: systematic review and meta-analysis - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/34046742/"},{"title":"3D cephalometric landmark detection by multiple stage deep reinforcement learning | Scientific Reports","url":"https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-021-97116-7"},{"title":"Deep learning for cephalometric landmark detection: systematic review and meta-analysis - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8310492/"},{"title":"A fully deep learning model for the automatic identification of cephalometric landmarks - PMC","url":"https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8479429/"},{"title":"Automatic identification of posteroanterior cephalometric landmarks using a novel deep learning algorithm: a comparative study with human experts | Scientific Reports","url":"https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-023-42870-z"},{"title":"Deep learning for cephalometric landmark detection: systematic review and meta-analysis | Clinical Oral Investigations","url":"https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00784-021-03990-w"},{"title":"A critical review of artificial intelligence based techniques for automatic prediction of cephalometric landmarks | Artificial Intelligence Review","url":"https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10462-025-11135-8"},{"title":"Accuracy of automated 3D cephalometric landmarks by deep learning algorithms: systematic review and meta-analysis | La radiologia medica","url":"https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11547-023-01629-2"},{"title":"Automatic Cephalometric Landmark Detection on X-ray Images Using a Deep-Learning Method","url":"https://www.mdpi.com/2076-3417/10/7/2547"},{"title":"Deep learning for automatic detection of cephalometric landmarks on lateral cephalometric radiographs using the Mask Region-based Convolutional Neural Network: a pilot study - ScienceDirect","url":"https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S2212440324000622"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of the current research on machine learning and deep learning for cephalometric landmark detection:

## Overview

The utilization of Deep Learning (DL) and Machine Learning (ML) algorithms has facilitated the emergence of automated systems capable of effectively detecting and localizing cephalometric landmarks. Automatic cephalometric landmark detection has emerged as a pivotal area of research that combines medical imaging, computer vision, and orthodontics.

## Key Findings from Research

### Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses

Deep learning (DL) has been increasingly employed for automated landmark detection for cephalometric purposes. A systematic review and meta-analysis was performed to assess the accuracy and underlying evidence for DL for cephalometric landmark detection on 2-D and 3-D radiographs.(no content)From 321 identified records, 19 studies (published 2017-2020) were included, all employing convolutional neural networks, mainly on 2-D lateral radiographs (n=15), using data from publicly available datasets (n=12), and testing the detection of a mean of 30 landmarks (range: 7-93).(no content)Existing DL models show consistent and largely high accuracy for automated detection of cephalometric landmarks. The majority of studies so far focused on 2-D imagery; data on 3-D imagery are sparse, but promising. Future studies should focus on demonstrating generalizability, robustness, and clinical usefulness of DL for this objective.

### Deep Learning Methods

Deep learning (DL), a subfield of machine learning, especially DL using convolutional neural networks (CNNs), has been demonstrated to be highly suitable for computer vision.(no content)One proposed deep learning model has a 2-step structure—a region of interest machine and a detection machine—each consisting of 8 convolution layers, 5 pooling layers, and 2 fully connected layers.

### 3D Cephalometric Detection

The lengthy time needed for manual landmarking has delayed the widespread adoption of three-dimensional (3D) cephalometry. Researchers have proposed automatic 3D cephalometric annotation systems based on multi-stage deep reinforcement learning (DRL) and volume-rendered imaging.(no content)Such systems show sufficient detection accuracy and stability for direct clinical applications, with a low level of detection error and low inter-individual variation (1.96 ± 0.78 mm).

### Performance Metrics

Deep learning algorithms, such as convolutional neural networks (CNNs), have been used increasingly to detect landmarks on lateral cephalograms automatically. These studies have reported that deep learning algorithms exhibit high accuracy in detecting landmarks at shorter time, achieving precision levels within the range of 2.0 mm, with successful detection rates surpassing 70% and 90% for the respective thresholds of 2 and 3 mm.(no content)Application of the Mask Region-based Convolutional Neural Network (Mask R-CNN) for automatic landmark detection on lateral cephalometric radiographs yielded a detection rate exceeding 98%, with acceptable average error and accuracy rate.

### Challenges

This technological advancement has resulted in a reduction in human error, as well as a significant improvement in the efficiency and speed of the process. Nevertheless, automatic landmark detection still embraces some problems, including the requirement for extensive and diverse datasets to effectively train DL models, as well as the necessity for algorithms to exhibit resilience in image quality variations.

Here are the results of my search for web-based cephalometric analysis tools online:

## Web-Based Cephalometric Analysis Tools

### 1. **CephX** (cephx.com)
CephX is a web-based service with no need to install, upgrade or maintain complex software packages.(no content)CephX provides instant cephalometric tracing and analysis to streamline the orthodontic pre-treatment process. Upload a 2D ceph or a 3D volume, and their AI will automatically construct a perfect ceph for tracing, giving you a complete analysis in seconds.(no content)You can choose from a range of generic analyses such as Rickets, Steiner, Sassouni, Jefferson and others, or have customized ones created.(no content)CephX has been providing orthodontic practitioners with imaging and ceph-tracing services for over 15 years and has processed close to 300,000 cases.

### 2. **WeDoCeph** (wedoceph.com)
Their AI engine will automatically trace cephalometric landmarks, planes, arcs, and both soft and hard tissue silhouettes which form a solid base for cephalometric analysis.(no content)Results of cephalometric analyses you submit are delivered to your repository in seconds. From there, you can select a patient with their done analysis to view, download, copy & paste or print the results.

### 3. **Ceph Assistant** (cephassistant.com)
Ceph Assistant is an advanced online software designed to help orthodontists perform quick and precise dental analyses. It offers versatile options, including profile photo analysis, frontal photo analysis and cephalometric analyses.(no content)You can choose from several popular cephalometric analysis types, such as Ricketts, Steiner, McNamara, Hasund, Eastman, and ABO, or customize your own analysis.(no content)Their cephalometric analysis software won first prize at the Vodafone Digital Award 2022 in the Digital Society category.

### 4. **Cephio** (cephio.com)
Cephio is an online program for analyzing cephalometric X-Rays. Powered by advanced artificial intelligence, it prepares tracing and landmark positioning automatically. You can choose analysis like Steiner, Jefferson or Bjork, upload X-Ray and save results as a PDF report.

### 5. **WebCeph** (webceph.com)
WebCeph is an innovative Artificial Intelligence driven online orthodontic and orthognathic platform. WebCeph supports automatic cephalometric tracing, cephalometric analysis, and more.(no content)The platform also supports visual treatment simulation, automatic superimposition, image archive and photo gallery.

### 6. **AudaxCeph** (audaxceph.com)
AudaxCeph allows you to choose from any of the existing analysis types (200+) or create your own customized analysis type by choosing desired measurements from the database.(no content)It automatically detects and places between 70 and 100 soft and hard tissue landmarks, reference planes, and silhouettes on lateral or PA cephalometric radiographs in just seconds.(no content)AudaxCeph software is MDR certified and FDA 510(k) cleared.

### 7. **EasyCeph** (easyceph.com)
Their web system allows you to make online cephalometric analyses without purchasing an application, licenses or paying annual fees.

### Research on Accuracy
Since its introduction in 1931, cephalometric analysis has become a widely used diagnostic and clinical tool in orthodontics. With rapid advancement in technology, the manual method is gradually being replaced by digital cephalometric analysis software, which has numerous benefits including reduction in radiation doses, facilitated image acquisition, archiving and sharing, faster measurements, and easily determined treatment plans.

### 7. **EasyCeph** (easyceph.com)
Their web system allows you to make online cephalometric analyses without purchasing an application, licenses or paying annual fees.

### Research on Accuracy
Since its introduction in 1931, cephalometric analysis has become a widely used diagnostic and clinical tool in orthodontics. With rapid advancement in technology, the manual method is gradually being replaced by digital cephalometric analysis software, which has numerous benefits including reduction in radiation doses, facilitated image acquisition, archiving and sharing, faster measurements, and easily determined treatment plans.

## Cephalometric Analysis in Orthodontics

### Overview
Cephalometric analysis evaluates lateral skull radiographs obtained with a cephalostat to determine skeletal patterns and assess treatment complexity.(no content)Cephalometric analysis is an integral part of modern orthodontics practice, aiding in the diagnosis and treatment of various dental and skeletal anomalies.

### Purpose and Applications
It is analysis of the dental and skeletal relationships of a human skull. It is frequently used by dentists, orthodontists, and oral and maxillofacial surgeons as a treatment planning tool.(no content)Cephalometric analysis depends on cephalometric radiography to study relationships between bony and soft tissue landmarks and can be used to diagnose facial growth abnormalities prior to treatment, in the middle of treatment to evaluate progress, or at the conclusion of treatment to ascertain that the goals of treatment have been met.

### Key Landmarks
The following are important cephalometric landmarks, which are points of reference serving as datum references in measurement and analysis.(no content)Landmark points can be joined by lines to form axes, vectors, angles, and planes. For example, the sella (S) and the nasion (N) are points that together form the sella-nasion line (SN or S-N), which can be projected into the SN plane.(no content)The SNA angle assesses the anteroposterior position of the maxilla relative to the anterior cranial base. The SNA angle is formed by connecting the sella, nasion, and A-point.

### Common Analysis Methods
Two of the more popular methods of analysis used in orthodontology are the Steiner analysis (named after Cecil C. Steiner) and the Downs analysis (named after William B. Downs).

### Recent Advances (2024-2025)

**AI and CNN-Based Landmark Detection:**
Cephalometric analysis is the primary diagnosis method in orthodontics. In our previous study, the algorithm was developed to estimate cephalometric landmarks from lateral facial photographs of patients with normal occlusion. This study evaluates the estimation accuracy by the algorithm trained on a dataset of 2320 patients with added malocclusion patients and the analysis values.(no content)Our new algorithm for estimating the landmarks from lateral facial photographs of malocclusion patients resulted in an error of less than 0.5 mm; the error in cephalometric analysis was less than 0.5°. Therefore, the algorithm can be clinically valuable.

**New Benchmark Datasets:**
Accurate identification and localization of cephalometric landmarks are crucial for diagnosing and quantifying anatomical abnormalities in orthodontics. Traditional manual annotation of these landmarks on lateral cephalograms (LCRs) is time-consuming and subject to inter- and intra-expert variability.(no content)Our dataset comprises 1,000 LCRs acquired from seven different imaging devices with varying resolutions, making it the most diverse and comprehensive collection to date. Each radiograph is meticulously annotated by clinical experts with 29 cephalometric landmarks, including the most extensive set of dental and soft tissue markers ever included in a public dataset.

### Digital vs Manual Tracing
Digital tracing using specialized software streamlines the cephalometric analysis process. The software automatically identifies anatomical landmarks on radiographs and calculates measurements. This also provides standards for comparison based on ethnicity, sex, and age while enabling predictions for soft tissue alterations, growth, and surgical outcomes.(no content)Both manual and digital tracing techniques are appropriate for cephalometric analysis. Average angular measurements and proportions are established for the general population, but these values serve as general guidelines. Standard measures may vary based on age, sex, and ethnicity.

Here are the key cephalometric landmarks you asked about:

## Main Cephalometric Landmarks

### Nasion (N)
Nasion is the most anterior point of the frontonasal suture in the midsagittal plane.

### Sella (S)
Sella is the midpoint of sella (the centre of sella turcica).(no content)It is the midpoint of the sella turcica (pituitary fossa).

### Pogonion (Pog)
Pogonion is the most anterior point of the bony chin in the midsagittal plane.

### Gonion (Go)
Gonion is a point at the intersection of lines tangent to the posterior border of the ramus (articulare–superior gonion) and the lower border of the mandible (menton–inferior gonion). Alternatively, it can be described as a point on the curvature of the angle of the mandible located by bisecting the angle formed by lines tangent to the posterior ramus and the inferior border of the mandible.

## Other Important Landmarks

Other commonly used cephalometric landmarks include Orbitale, Porion, Basion, Point A, Point B, Anterior Nasal Spine, Menton, Gnathion, Articulare, Condylion, Prosthion, Infradentale, Posterior Nasal Spine, and Ptm Point.

## Key Planes and Angles

The sella (S) and the nasion (N) are points that together form the sella-nasion line (SN or S-N), which can be projected into the SN plane.(no content)Important angles include ANB (A point, nasion, B point) which indicates skeletal relationship between maxilla and mandible; SNA (sella, nasion, A point) indicates maxillary position; and SNB (sella, nasion, B point) indicates mandibular position.(no content)The mandibular plane may be constructed using either Gonion-Menton, Gonion-Gnathion, or tangent points on the inferior border of the mandible.

Based on my search, I found several publicly available benchmark datasets for cephalometric landmark detection:

## Publicly Available Cephalometric Landmark Datasets

### 1. **Aariz Dataset**
Aariz is a benchmark dataset comprising 1000 lateral cephalometric radiographs (LCRs), acquired from 7 different radiographic imaging devices with varying resolutions, making it one of the most diverse and comprehensive cephalometric datasets available to date.(no content)Each radiograph has been meticulously annotated by clinical experts with 29 cephalometric landmarks, featuring a rich set of dental and soft-tissue points. In addition to landmark annotation, Cervical Vertebral Maturation (CVM) stages are labelled for each patient, positioning Aariz as the first standard resource for CVM classification.

- **Availability**: Aariz has officially made its debut in Nature Scientific Data (31/07/2025). The dataset is now publicly available, offering the research community access to 1000 annotated cephalometric X-rays with 29 anatomical landmarks.
- **License**: Available under a Creative Commons Attribution (CC-BY) license, ensuring compliance with patient privacy and ethical standards.
- **GitHub**: https://github.com/manwaarkhd/aariz-cephalometric-dataset

### 2. **CL-Detection 2023 Dataset**
The "Cephalometric Landmark Detection (CL-Detection)" dataset is the largest publicly available and comprehensive dataset for cephalometric landmark detection. This multi-center and multi-vendor dataset includes 600 lateral X-ray images with 38 landmarks acquired with different equipment from three medical centers.

- The dataset consists of 600 2D lateral X-ray images from two existing datasets: ISBI challenge (400 cases), PKU cephalogram dataset (102 cases) and a new dataset from Shenzhen General Hospital (92 cases).
- **Results**: The best methods achieved a mean detection rate of 75.719% and a mean radial error of 1.518 mm.
- **Website**: Both the dataset and detailed results are publicly available online at https://cl-detection2023.grand-challenge.org/.

### 3. **CephAdoAdu Dataset**
For the task of cephalometric landmark detection across age groups, a new benchmark dataset named CephAdoAdu was collected, with both adolescent and adult cases, distinguishing it from existing datasets that focus on only one age group.

- The whole dataset is randomly divided into training set (400 images), validation set (300 images), and testing set (300 images).
- Code and dataset are made public at https://github.com/ShanghaiTech-IMPACT/CeLDA/.

### Evaluation Metrics
Common evaluation metrics include Mean Radial Error (MRE) with its Standard Deviation (SD), and Success Detection Rate (SDR) at multiple clinically relevant thresholds (2.0 mm, 2.5 mm, 3.0 mm, and 4.0 mm).

Here are the results of your search for dental landmark detection computer vision side profile segmentation:

## Key Research Areas and Methods

### 2D Cephalometric Landmark Detection
"Localization of the craniofacial landmarks from lateral cephalograms is a fundamental task in cephalometric analysis. The automation of the corresponding tasks has thus been the subject of intense research over the past decades."(no content)The CL-Detection (Cephalometric Landmark Detection) dataset is the largest publicly available dataset for this task, containing 600 lateral X-ray images with 38 landmarks from three medical centers.(no content)A common approach is a two-step method that first extracts a region of interest (ROI) patch for each landmark by registering test images to training images, then uses pre-trained networks with a ResNet50 backbone to detect each landmark in each ROI patch.

### Challenges in Side Profile/Lateral View Detection
Key challenges include overlapping craniofacial structures and poor contrast in X-ray images, as well as landmark occlusion by dental braces, implants, or lead shields.(no content)CNN-based algorithms excel at capturing local information but struggle with perceiving occluded landmarks. The intrinsic shape constraints inherent in heatmap-based methods are absent, resulting in predicted landmarks appearing at inappropriate locations.

### 3D Dental Model Segmentation and Landmark Detection
Tooth segmentation and anatomical landmark detection are crucial for orthodontic treatment planning. Orthodontists need to segment teeth and annotate corresponding anatomical landmarks on 3D dental models to analyze and rearrange tooth positions for treatments like clear aligners.(no content)Automatic and accurate tooth segmentation on 3D dental point clouds is pivotal in computer-aided dentistry. New Transformer-based methods like PointRegion can process entire point clouds at low cost while modeling global contexts.

### Advanced Deep Learning Approaches
Recent methods leverage point cloud learning through transformer architectures. Point Transformer v3 inspired modules capture meaningful geometric and anatomical features, processed by lightweight decoders to predict per-point distances with graph-based non-minima suppression.(no content)DeepFuse is a multi-modal deep learning framework that integrates information from lateral cephalograms, CBCT volumes, and digital dental models to simultaneously perform landmark detection and treatment outcome prediction using attention-guided fusion mechanisms.

### Semi-Supervised Learning Approaches
Semi-supervised learning methods are being used for automatic segmentation of 3D CBCT images and landmark detection for orthognathic surgery planning, achieving dice scores of 93.41% and 96.89% for maxillary and mandibular segmentation tasks.

### Segmentation Networks for Dental Radiographs
Convolutional Neural Networks like U-Net have been widely used for medical image segmentation. Applying U-Net on panoramic dental images is challenging due to varying shape, size, and frequency of different restoration types.

The automation of the corresponding tasks has thus been the subject of intense research over the past decades."(no content)The CL-Detection (Cephalometric Landmark Detection) dataset is the largest publicly available dataset for this task, containing 600 lateral X-ray images with 38 landmarks from three medical centers.(no content)A common approach is a two-step method that first extracts a region of interest (ROI) patch for each landmark by registering test images to training images, then uses pre-trained networks with a ResNet50 backbone to detect each landmark in each ROI patch.

### Challenges in Side Profile/Lateral View Detection
Key challenges include overlapping craniofacial structures and poor contrast in X-ray images, as well as landmark occlusion by dental braces, implants, or lead shields.(no content)CNN-based algorithms excel at capturing local information but struggle with perceiving occluded landmarks. The intrinsic shape constraints inherent in heatmap-based methods are absent, resulting in predicted landmarks appearing at inappropriate locations.

### 3D Dental Model Segmentation and Landmark Detection
Tooth segmentation and anatomical landmark detection are crucial for orthodontic treatment planning. Orthodontists need to segment teeth and annotate corresponding anatomical landmarks on 3D dental models to analyze and rearrange tooth positions for treatments like clear aligners.(no content)Automatic and accurate tooth segmentation on 3D dental point clouds is pivotal in computer-aided dentistry. New Transformer-based methods like PointRegion can process entire point clouds at low cost while modeling global contexts.

### Advanced Deep Learning Approaches
Recent methods leverage point cloud learning through transformer architectures. Point Transformer v3 inspired modules capture meaningful geometric and anatomical features, processed by lightweight decoders to predict per-point distances with graph-based non-minima suppression.(no content)DeepFuse is a multi-modal deep learning framework that integrates information from lateral cephalograms, CBCT volumes, and digital dental models to simultaneously perform landmark detection and treatment outcome prediction using attention-guided fusion mechanisms.

### Semi-Supervised Learning Approaches
Semi-supervised learning methods are being used for automatic segmentation of 3D CBCT images and landmark detection for orthognathic surgery planning, achieving dice scores of 93.41% and 96.89% for maxillary and mandibular segmentation tasks.

### Segmentation Networks for Dental Radiographs
Convolutional Neural Networks like U-Net have been widely used for medical image segmentation. Applying U-Net on panoramic dental images is challenging due to varying shape, size, and frequency of different restoration types.

Here's what I found about Steiner analysis cephalometric landmarks and reference points:

## Steiner Cephalometric Analysis Overview

Cecil C. Steiner developed Steiner Analysis in 1953.(no content)Throughout the years, Steiner's analysis has been generally the most commonly used cephalometric analysis, providing a series of measurements essential for diagnosis and treatment planning.

### Reference Plane

Steiner used the SELLA to NASION line as a reference plane for his analysis. This line represents the anterior cranial base.(no content)He used the S–N plane as his reference line in comparison to the FH (Frankfort Horizontal) plane due to difficulty in identifying the orbitale and porion.

### Key Cephalometric Landmarks

The main landmarks used in Steiner analysis include:

**Nasion (N):** The most anterior point of the frontonasal suture.(no content)**Sella point (S):** The geometric point located in the center of the sella turcica of the sphenoid bone.(no content)**Point A:** The deepest point of the anterior concavity of the maxilla.(no content)**Point B:** The deepest point of the anterior border of the mandibular symphysis.(no content)**Pogonion (Pg):** The most prominent point of the anterior border of the mandibular symphysis.(no content)**Menton (Me):** The lowest point on the symphysis of the jaw.(no content)**Gonion (Go) and Gnathion (Gn):** The mandibular plane is drawn between gonion and gnathion.

### Three Areas of Analysis

Steiner's analysis focused on three areas of concern: skeletal, dental, and soft tissue. Skeletally, the maxilla and mandible are related to the cranial base (SN) through SNA, SNB, ANB, occlusal plane and mandibular plane (GoGn).(no content)The dental values include the maxillary incisor position, mandibular incisor position, interincisal angle and lower incisor to chin. These values relate the upper and lower incisors to each other and to the upper and lower dental bases.(no content)The soft tissue value, particularly the Steiner's line (S line), measures the upper and lower lip protrusion. The S line runs from the soft tissue contour of the chin to the tip of the nose.

### Key Angular Measurements

The **SNA angle** is the posteroinferior angle between the SN and NA planes. It places the upper jaw, sagittally, with respect to the base of the skull and establishes whether the maxilla is protruded or retruded.(no content)**SNB** (sella, nasion, B point) indicates whether or not the mandible is normal, prognathic, or retrognathic.(no content)The **ANB angle** is the difference between the two anterior angles and establishes the relationship of the maxilla and mandible with each other in the anteroposterior direction. It is one of the indicators for the differential diagnosis of skeletal/dental class.(no content)The angle of the occlusal plane to S-N is measured, with a mean reading of 14°.(no content)The mandibular plane angle (formed by Go-Gn to the S-N plane) has a mean reading of 32°.

### Limitations

Some of the drawbacks of the Steiner analysis includes its reliability on the point nasion. Nasion as a point is known not to be stable due to its growth early in life.

Here are the search results for soft tissue landmarks in cephalometry, facial profile, and nasolabial angle:

## Soft Tissue Landmarks in Cephalometry and the Nasolabial Angle

### Definition of Nasolabial Angle
The nasolabial angle is the angle formed by a line tangent to the base of the nose and a line tangent to the upper lip.(no content)It is one of the most critical parameters of the soft tissue profile when orthodontic treatment is required.

### Key Soft Tissue Landmarks
The anatomical points most frequently used for the analysis of facial soft tissues include the soft tissue Pogonion (Pog´), the Upper Lip (Ls), Lower Lip, Subnasale (Sn), and Soft tissue Menton (Me´), all of which are essential for analyzing facial profile and projection.(no content)The nasolabial angle measurement uses a tangent drawn from the subnasale (Sn) point to the philtrum of the upper lip through the labral superior (Ls) point and to the nose through the columella nasi (Cm) point.

### Clinical Applications
Lateral cephalograms have been the primary and most commonly used radiographs in evaluating both hard and soft tissue profiles for orthodontic patients. Soft tissue cephalometric analysis has been divided into two parts: subnasal and general. The subnasal profile involves the area under the nose and evaluates lip position relative to the nose and chin.(no content)The general profile assessment is often performed using the nasolabial angle, Z-angle, 0-degree meridian, facial angle, and lip/chin prominence.

### Normal Values and Variations
The ST facial angle indicated a straight profile in both genders (92.68±2.89 in males and 92.65±3.11 in females), with a nasolabial angle slightly more obtuse compared to Caucasian values (109.03±12.05 in males and 109.15±8.84 in females).(no content)Significant differences exist between males and females, as well as between different ethnic samples. These results suggest that both gender and ethnicity must be taken into account when establishing normal values for the nasal form and its relationship to other cranial structures.

### Effects of Treatment
Studies of extraction treatments with angle class I anomalies showed an increased nasolabial angle and more retruded upper and lower lips in extraction patients.(no content)The nasolabial angle is among the traits that remain relatively constant during growth, along with facial profile angle and lower face percentage.

### Analysis Methods
Cephalometric measurements are conducted using reference points, angles, distances, and measurement proportions. Various parameters exist for the cephalometric analysis of soft tissues, including those established by Legan, Burstone, McNamara, Scheideman, Holdaway, Steiner, Downs, Ricketts, Rakosi, and Schwarz.

Nasion (N), sella (S),... | Download Scientific Diagram","url":"https://www.researchgate.net/figure/The-major-landmarks-used-in-McNamaras-analysis-Nasion-N-sella-S-basion-Ba_fig1_228662366"},{"title":"McNamara Analysis ⏤ Cephalometric Services Platform","url":"https://www.analyzeceph.com/mcnamara-analysis/"},{"title":"Cone-Beam Computed Tomography-Based Three-Dimensional McNamara Cephalometric Analysis - PubMed","url":"https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29381618/"},{"title":"Chinese Norms of McNamara's Cephalometric Analysis","url":"https://meridian.allenpress.com/angle-orthodontist/article/77/1/12/58070/Chinese-Norms-of-McNamara-s-Cephalometric-Analysis"}]

Here's what I found about the McNamara cephalometric analysis landmarks and technique:

## Overview

Dr. James McNamara developed a cephalometric analysis method in 1984 to evaluate orthodontic and orthognathic surgery patients.(no content)This method is used for evaluation and treatment planning. In the analysis of a single film, the positions of the maxilla and mandible are related to cranial structures and to each other. Criteria for evaluation of the anteroposterior and vertical positions of the upper and lower incisors are provided, as is the documentation of the standards for each of the measures.

## Five Sections of Analysis

The analysis divides the craniofacial skeleton into five sections: maxilla to cranial base, maxilla to mandible, mandible to cranial base, dentition, and airway. Linear measurements of landmarks and planes are compared to normative standards to assess relationships.

## Key Landmarks

The major landmarks used in McNamara's analysis include: Nasion (N), sella (S), basion (Ba), porion (Po), orbitale (Or), anterior nasal spine (ANS), posterior nasal spine (PNS), pterygomaxillary fissure (PTM), point A (A), point B (B), pogonion (Pog), gnathion (Gn), menton (Me), gonion (Go), articular (Ar), condylion (Co), upper incisal apex (UIA), upper incisal edge (UIE), lower incisal edge (LIE), and lower incisal apex (LIA).

## Key Measurements

The measurements used in McNamara cephalometric analysis include:
1. A-N perpendicular (mm)
2. Effective mandibular length (Co-Gn, mm)
3. Effective midfacial length (Co-A, mm)
4. Maxillo-mandibular difference (Mx-Md difference, mm)
5. Lower anterior facial height (ANS-Me, mm)
6. Mandibular plane angle (FH/MP, degrees)
7. Facial axis angle
8. Pog-N perpendicular (mm)
9. Ui-A (mm)
10. Li-APog (mm)

## Planes and Measurements for Skeletal Study

According to McNamara, the skeletal and dental components of the face are composed of the following planes and measurements: Nasion perpendiculars (aka McNamara's Vertical), linear distance from point A to nasion perpendicular, linear distance from point pog to nasion perpendicular, maxillary length, mandibular length, and lower anterior facial height.(no content)The planes and measurements used for analysis of the airways are upper pharynx diameter and the lower pharynx diameter. The upper pharyngeal width is the smallest distance from the posterior pharyngeal wall to anterior half of the soft palate outline.

## Advantages

There are three main advantages of the McNamara analysis. Firstly it depends largely on linear measurements rather than angles. It analyzes the interarch relationship in the vertical plane as well as sagittal making them into one single integrated unit. Lastly, it helps to diagnose external conditions in the airway.

## Normative Standards

Standards for this analysis were derived from 3 sources: lateral cephalograms of children comprising the Bolton standards, selected values from a group of untreated children from the Burlington Orthodontic Research Center, and 111 young adults from Ann Arbor, Michigan, having good to excellent facial configurations.(no content)McNamara's Jr. cephalometric analysis is a tool to diagnose dental and skeletal discrepancies and is widely used, guiding diagnosis for surgical procedures to be performed or for the use of functional devices.

Here are the search results for **side profile measurement facial proportions orthodontics technical guide**:

## Key Findings

### Facial Profile Types
Facial profiles can be determined from the side of the face, categorized into three types: straight, convex, and concave profiles.(no content)Proffit et al. (2007) classified the faces into straight, convex, and concave. A convex profile indicates a skeletal Class II jaw relationship, whereas a concave profile indicates a skeletal Class III jaw relationship.

### Vertical Facial Proportions
The face can be divided into thirds - the upper, middle, and lower third. The upper third is from hair line to Glabella point (above bridge of nose), the middle third is from the Glabella to the Subnasale, and the lower third is from the Subnasale to Menton (lowest point on chin).(no content)The part from the Subnasale to Stomion should be half the dimension from the Stomion to menton - in other words, the lower third facial height is further subdivided into a one third/two thirds proportion.

### Horizontal Facial Proportions
Vertically, the face is split into fifths. Each eye occupies one fifth, the width between the eyes another fifth, and the breadth of the nasal base the last fifth. These measurements are vital for ensuring that dental corrections respect the natural symmetry of the face.

### Angular Measurements
Angular measurements measured by Peck and Peck in profilometric analysis in both vertical and horizontal dimensions include a maxillofacial angle, nasomaxillary angle, nasal angle, maxillary angle, and mandibular angle which yield characteristics of the esthetically pleasing profile.(no content)The proportion of the lower face can be defined within a narrow range. The Z angle measurement and the profile line give a critical description of lower face relationship and eliminate the vagueness of "eye judgment."(no content)With normal FMA, IMPA, FMIA, and ANB measurements in the adult, the normal Z angle is 80 degrees.

### Profile Line and Lip Position
The lip relation can be judged accurately by relating it to the profile line. The upper lip should be tangent to the line; the lower lip should be tangent or slightly behind the profile line.(no content)Measurement of the profile angle can identify and localize the chin point. Even though the length of the nose and the thickness of the lips and chin may vary, the proper chin position may eventually justify a pleasing facial profile among different ethnic origins.

### Golden Ratio in Facial Aesthetics
The Golden Ratio, approximately 1.618, is used as a standard for aesthetic perfection. In facial aesthetics, it is applied to measure the ideal widths and heights of facial features. For instance, the width of the mouth is ideally φ times the width of the nose.

### Facial Types Classification
Dolichocephalic (Long Face): It is a long and narrow face shape with a higher lower part. In individuals with long faces, the lower jaw grows downwards, and in this case, the chin appears further back.(no content)Brachycephalic (Short Face): A face type seen with a wide and short shape. The chin may be positioned behind or in front, or there may be deep closure in this area. In this case, the lower jaw grows forward.

### Clinical Application
Facial profile analysis is one of the assessments used to determine the diagnosis and orthodontic treatment plan by measuring an individual's face from the side view. In orthodontic treatment, soft tissue evaluation, especially the determination of facial profile, is an essential component used to assess the relationship between the jaws and teeth in order to establish a diagnosis and treatment plan.

Based on my search results, here's what I found about MediaPipe facial landmarks and their relationship to cephalometric landmarks:

## MediaPipe Face Landmarks Overview

MediaPipe Face Mesh is a solution that estimates 468 3D face landmarks in real-time even on mobile devices.(no content)It employs machine learning (ML) to infer the 3D facial surface, requiring only a single camera input without the need for a dedicated depth sensor.(no content)The task outputs 3-dimensional face landmarks, blendshape scores (coefficients representing facial expression) to infer detailed facial surfaces in real-time, and transformation matrices to perform the transformations required for effects rendering.

## Technical Details

For 3D face landmarks, they employed transfer learning and trained a network with several objectives: the network simultaneously predicts 3D landmark coordinates on synthetic rendered data and 2D semantic contours on annotated real-world data. The resulting network provided reasonable 3D landmark predictions not just on synthetic but also on real-world data.

## Medical/Surgical Applications

The use of robotics, computer vision, and their applications is becoming increasingly widespread in various fields, including medicine. Many face detection algorithms have found applications in neurosurgery, ophthalmology, and plastic surgery.(no content)MediaPipe is an open source framework based on the BlazeFace method, and one study aimed to evaluate its algorithm to detect facial landmarks under realistic operating room conditions. The experiment involves testing the algorithm in controlled medical conditions using a robotic arm with an attached 3D camera and an anthropomorphic phantom. Furthermore, the study sought to investigate whether MediaPipe can be used to estimate the pose of the patient's head during the planning and execution of surgical procedures.

## Key Finding

The search results did not return specific research on **mapping MediaPipe's 468 facial landmarks directly to traditional cephalometric landmarks** used in orthodontics/craniofacial analysis. While MediaPipe is being explored for surgical applications, the specific correlation or mapping between MediaPipe landmark indices and cephalometric points (like Nasion, Pogonion, Menton, etc.) doesn't appear in these results.

Here are the results of my search for maxillofacial surgery planning software with 3D facial analysis:

## Leading Maxillofacial Surgery Planning Software with 3D Facial Analysis

### Commercial Software Solutions

**1. PROPLAN CMF™ (Materialise)**
PROPLAN CMF™ empowers surgeons to make critical decisions preoperatively and helps to ensure better surgical outcomes. The software's dedicated workflows cover orthognathic procedures as well as mandible and midface reconstructions and distractions. Key features include:
- Generating 2D or 3D visualizations of the patient's anatomy and planning orthognathic procedures, mandible and midface reconstructions, osteotomies, and bone fragment repositioning.
- Running accurate soft tissue simulations to visualize the patient's face post operation.
- Performing accurate 3D cephalometric analyses and designing/exporting splints and anatomical models to be 3D printed.

**2. VSP Craniomaxillofacial Solutions (3D Systems)**
Surgery may be made more predictable and efficient through visualization of the anatomy through the planning process and by identifying where bony overlaps and gaps exist, all before surgery. More than 10 years of research and development have culminated in a streamlined product offering for orthognathic surgical planning.
- Key features include the ability to accurately integrate occlusal data from high-resolution scans of stone models and fabricate guides, splints and other tools using 3D printing technologies.
- Provides real time 3D bony movement and cephalometric analysis.

**3. Planmeca Romexis® CMF Surgery**
The Planmeca Romexis® CMF Surgery module is an advanced orthognathic software for preparing virtual surgical treatment plans. It provides surgeons with the means to evaluate cases and to generate intermediate and final splints based on the target occlusion and position of the jaw.
- The software allows you to enrich planning with tools for following anatomic landmarks and measurements between them during orthognathic treatment simulations, and can be combined with 3D Cephalometric Analysis.

**4. Materialise Mimics Enlight CMF**
Mimics Enlight CMF is intended for use as a software interface and imaging segmentation system for the transfer of medical imaging information. It's also intended to support the diagnostic and treatment planning process of cranio-maxillofacial procedures, providing visualization, measurement and design tools.
- Materialise software can provide a realistic, accurate forecast of the patient's facial appearance after surgery.

### Research and Clinical Applications

Virtual Surgical Planning (VSP) has revolutionized the way craniomaxillofacial surgeries are planned and executed. It uses 3D imaging computer software to visualize and simulate a surgical procedure.(no content)Digital X-ray systems and cone beam technology assist with determining the exact diagnosis and obtaining a 3-dimensional model for surgical treatment planning. This radiographic technology then enables surgeons to use virtual surgical planning (VSP) to plan various surgical procedures.(no content)For VR-based simulators, models are created based on CT volume images using Slicer 5.6.2 and 3Ds Max 2024.2. Slicer is software for processing CT volume images, while 3Ds Max is used for post-processing the models.

Here are the search results for "cephalometric automated detection CNN architecture paper 2024":

## Key Papers on Automated Cephalometric Landmark Detection with CNN Architectures (2024)

### 1. Multi-Scale 3D Cephalometric Landmark Detection (November 2024)
This study proposes a multi-scale 3D CNN-based approach utilizing direct regression to improve the accuracy of maxillofacial landmark detection.(no content)The method employs a coarse-to-fine framework, first identifying landmarks in a global context and then refining their positions using localized 3D patches.(no content)A clinical dataset of 150 CT scans from maxillofacial surgery patients, annotated with 30 anatomical landmarks, was used for training and evaluation. The proposed method achieved an average RMSE of 2.238 mm, outperforming conventional 3D CNN architectures.

### 2. Two-Stage Cascaded CNN (MIUA 2024)
This work presents a novel two-stage cascaded convolutional neural network (CNN) architecture for automatic cephalometric landmark detection.(no content)The architecture leverages a newly developed multi-modal, multi-resolution benchmark dataset, named "Aariz", specifically designed for this task.(no content)The framework achieved an overall mean radial error (MRE) of 1.789 ± 6.548 on the test dataset, adequately within the clinically accepted range of 2 mm. Additionally, the framework demonstrated success detection rates (SDRs) of 78.44% and 94.44% within the 2 mm and 4 mm ranges, respectively.

### 3. CEPHMark-Net - Two-Stage Regression Framework (2024)
This repository presents state-of-the-art automatic cephalometric landmark detection framework that utilizes a novel multi-head Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). The framework consists of two primary modules: landmark detection and landmark refinement, both leveraging a shared backbone neural network.(no content)Published in Expert Systems with Applications (2024) by Khalid et al., the paper is titled "A two-stage regression framework for automated cephalometric landmark detection incorporating semantically fused anatomical features and multi-head refinement loss."

### 4. Progressive Enhancement Framework (DMIP 2024)
This paper proposes a novel framework that enables targeted learning and extraction of structural and medical features based on neural network. Specifically, the framework's key components comprise Contour Sharpener, Coupling Transformer, and Progressively Targeted Feature Extraction Networks (PT-FENet).

### 5. VGG-16 Based Deep Learning Approach (2024)
The VGG-16 model can automatically extract relevant features from cephalometric images allowing it to accurately detect anatomical landmarks. It is also shown that fine-tuning the pre-trained VGG-16 model on cephalometric data can improve its performance.

### 6. DeepFuse Framework (Multi-modal Approach)
The DeepFuse framework introduces several key innovations: (1) a flexible multi-modal architecture that accommodates variable input modalities, including lateral cephalograms, CBCT volumes, and digital dental models; (2) an attention-guided feature fusion mechanism that dynamically weights modality-specific contributions based on their diagnostic relevance.

Based on the search results, here's information about the ISBI cephalometric landmark detection challenge datasets and competitions:

## ISBI Cephalometric Landmark Detection Challenges

### Historical Challenges

IEEE International Symposium on Biomedical Imaging (ISBI) hosted the challenge of Automatic Cephalometric Landmark Detection for Diagnosis in Cephalometric X-ray Images in both 2014 and 2015.

### IEEE ISBI 2014 Challenge Dataset
The dataset comprised of 300 cephalometric radiographs collected from 300 patients, ranging in age from 6 to 60 years.(no content)The goal of Automatic Cephalometric X-Ray Landmark Detection Challenge 2014 was to investigate a suitable automatic landmark detection technology for cephalometric x-ray images and provide a standard evaluation framework with a clinical dataset.

### IEEE ISBI 2015 Challenge Dataset
The dataset comprised of 400 cephalometric radiographs collected from 400 patients. The skull radiographs were obtained using the Soredex CRANEX® Excel Ceph machine and processed with Soredex SorCom software. The resolution of each TIFF-formatted image is 1935 × 2400 with pixel spacing of 0.1mm. For evaluation, 19 landmarks were manually annotated in each radiograph and subsequently reviewed by two experienced orthodontists.(no content)Among 400 cephalograms, 150 radiographs were designated for training and 250 for testing. The 250 test images were further divided into Test1 dataset with 150 images and Test2 dataset with 100 images.(no content)Each image is annotated with ground truth data produced by two experienced medical doctors.

### CEPHA29 Challenge (ISBI 2023)
The Automatic Cephalometric Landmark Detection Challenge (CEPHA29) was organized in conjunction with IEEE International Symposium on Biomedical Imaging (ISBI 2023). It provides a state-of-the-art dataset consisting of 1000 cephalometric X-ray images acquired from 7 different radiographic imaging devices. Each cephalogram in the dataset has been labelled by clinical experts with the 29 most commonly used cephalometric landmarks.(no content)29 international teams participated in this challenge.

### CL-Detection 2023 (MICCAI)
The CL-Detection 2023 cephalometric landmark detection challenge was held with the 2023 MICCAI conference.(no content)To ensure fair comparison, the data used to train algorithms is restricted to the data provided by the challenge. Pre-trained models from IEEE ISBI 2015 or 2014 challenges or PKU cephalogram dataset are not allowed to be used.

These datasets have become standard benchmarks for evaluating automatic cephalometric landmark detection methods in orthodontic and craniofacial analysis research.

Here are the search results for Ricketts cephalometric analysis in orthodontics:

## Ricketts Cephalometric Analysis in Orthodontics

### Overview
Ricketts Cephalometric Analysis, created and developed by Robert Ricketts in 1969, is a computerized analysis tool. It is one of the most important methods in assessing, tracking and diagnosing routine patient growth patterns in the craniofacial complex.(no content)The technique of cephalometric analysis according to Ricketts is an important tool in orthodontic diagnostics, which allows for accurate and comprehensive analysis of craniofacial structures.

### History and Development
Ricketts published two papers in 1960 in which he showed his work of using cephalometric X-rays on 1000 patients in his clinic. Some of his contributions to the field of orthodontics included the first straight wire bracket .018 inch slot (1970), cephalometric analysis which allowed clinicians to compare their patients with norms based on age, sex, and race, and the first cephalometric system to forecast treatment results plus growth in treatment planning.

### Key Measurements
A system of five measurements from x-ray tracings was designed to provide a sensible method of informing the orthodontist of facial form and denture position. The five measurements were (1) the facial angle, (2) the XY axis angle, (3) the measure of contour, and (4 and 5) the relationship of the upper and lower incisors to the APo plane. These angles and measurements proved to be indicators of facial depth, facial height, and profile contour.(no content)The analysis outlines 11 parameters that provide an overview of a patient's craniofacial and dental growth patterns, including measurements of facial angle, convexity, lip position, and tooth inclination. The analysis orients the face and mandible to the cranium to understand a patient's growth and develop optimal treatment plans that integrate facial growth patterns.

### Specific Parameters (Example Values from Research)
Based on Ricketts' analysis, typical cephalometric measurements include: Facial axis: 85.7°, Facial depth: 88.6°, Mandibular plane angle: 27.4°, Mandibular arch: 34.2 mm, Convexity of point A: 4.1 mm, Denture height: 46.9 mm, L1 to A-Pog: 27.9°, L1 to A-Pog (linear measurement): 6.6 mm, Upper molar to PtV: 18.6 mm, Lower lip to E-plane: 2.1 mm.

### Reference Planes and Landmarks
The Facial Axis is a line from PT point through cephalometric Gnathion which normally interacts BA-NA at right angles. The Cranial Base Plane is a line formed by connecting BA-NA; in normal Caucasians it forms 30° with the FH plane.(no content)The lower lip protrusion is evaluated by measuring the lower lip from an aesthetic line (E-line) constructed by joining the tip of the nose and the tip of the chin.

### Purpose and Clinical Application
The purpose of the analysis encompasses the 4 C's of cephalometrics: 1. To characterize or describe the existing conditions. 2. To compare one individual with another or the same individual with himself at a later time. 3. To classify certain descriptions into various categories. 4. To communicate all these aspects to the clinician, to a fellow research worker, or to a parent.

### Limitations
A strong dependence of the method on such parameters as ethnicity, age, gender, and face type was revealed.(no content)Like any other transmission radiographs, lateral cephalometric radiographs collapse a three-dimensional structure into a two-dimensional plane. This results in difficult landmark identification especially for bilateral structures. Furthermore, due to non-parallel x-ray projection, structures more proximal to the x-ray source appear more magnified than those proximal to the detector.

content.text:
Excellent research. Now I have comprehensive information to compile. Let me provide a thorough analysis report.

## Comprehensive Analysis: Cephalometric Analysis in Orthodontics and Maxillofacial Surgery

Based on extensive research, here's a detailed analysis of the cephalometric analysis field and how side profile landmark detection is performed professionally:

---

## 1. CRITICAL LANDMARKS FOR CEPHALOMETRIC ANALYSIS

### Hard Tissue (Skeletal) Landmarks

The most essential landmarks used in professional cephalometric analysis include:

**Cranial Base:**
- **Sella (S)** - Center of the sella turcica (pituitary fossa)
- **Nasion (N)** - Most anterior point of the frontonasal suture
- **Basion (Ba)** - Most inferior point of the foramen magnum
- **Porion (Po)** - Most superior point of the external auditory meatus
- **Orbitale (Or)** - Lowest point of the orbital rim

**Maxillary Landmarks:**
- **Point A** - Deepest point of anterior concavity of maxilla
- **Anterior Nasal Spine (ANS)** - Most anterior point of maxilla
- **Posterior Nasal Spine (PNS)** - Posterior end of nasal septum

**Mandibular Landmarks:**
- **Point B** - Deepest point of anterior concavity of mandibular symphysis
- **Pogonion (Pog)** - Most anterior/prominent point of chin
- **Menton (Me)** - Most inferior point of mandibular symphysis
- **Gonion (Go)** - Intersection of posterior ramus and lower border tangent lines
- **Gnathion (Gn)** - Most anterior-inferior point of chin
- **Articulare (Ar)** - Intersection of neck of condyle and posterior border of ramus
- **Condylion (Co)** - Most superior point of mandibular condyle

### Soft Tissue Landmarks

Professional analysis now includes extensive soft tissue evaluation:

- **Pogonion' (Pog')** - Soft tissue chin prominence
- **Menton' (Me')** - Soft tissue lower chin point
- **Upper Lip (Ls)** - Labral superior (lip contour)
- **Lower Lip** - Lower lip contour
- **Subnasale (Sn)** - Point where nasal septum meets upper lip
- **Columella Nasi (Cm)** - Tip of nose cartilage
- **Soft tissue profile** - Nasal profile, lip protrusion

---

## 2. THE FRANKFORT HORIZONTAL PLANE

### Definition and Importance

The **Frankfort Horizontal (FH) plane** is one of the most critical reference planes in cephalometric analysis. It is defined as the plane passing through:
- **Bilateral Porions (PoR and PoL)** - The superior points of the external auditory meatus on both sides
- **Left Orbitale (OrL)** - The lowest point of the left orbital rim

This plane represents the natural head position and has been the standard reference since the Frankfort Craniometric Agreement of 1882.

### Clinical Application

- **Frankfort Mandibular Angle (FMA):** Normal range is 25 ± 5 degrees
  - High-angle patients: 30+ degrees
  - Low-angle patients: 20 or fewer degrees
- Used as reference for measuring skeletal and dental relationships
- Alternative to S-N (Sella-Nasion) plane in Steiner analysis when orbitale and porion are difficult to identify

### 3D Considerations

Recent research emphasizes that the **definition of the FH plane significantly influences measurement interpretation** in 3D cephalometry. Studies show:
- Significant and undesirable measurement differences can be produced by varying FH plane definition
- "Dental" and "foraminal" landmarks are more reliable than conventional landmarks for establishing reference planes
- Despite poor individual landmark reliability, the conventional FH plane provides reliable 3D reference for craniofacial orientation

---

## 3. MAJOR ANALYSIS METHODOLOGIES

Professional cephalometric analysis uses several established systems:

### Steiner Analysis (1953)
- Most commonly used method historically
- **Reference plane:** S-N (Sella-Nasion)
- **Key measurements:**
  - SNA angle: Maxillary position relative to cranial base (normal ~82°)
  - SNB angle: Mandibular position (normal ~80°)
  - ANB angle: Maxillo-mandibular relationship (normal ~2°)
  - Mandibular plane angle (GoGn to S-N): ~32°
  - Occlusal plane angle to S-N: ~14°
- **Three areas:** Skeletal, dental, soft tissue
- **Steiner Line (S-line):** Measures lip protrusion from soft tissue profile

### McNamara Analysis (1984)
- Analyzes five sections: maxilla to cranial base, maxilla to mandible, mandible to cranial base, dentition, and airway
- **Emphasizes linear measurements over angles**
- **Key measurements include:**
  - A-N perpendicular
  - Effective mandibular length (Co-Gn)
  - Maxillo-mandibular difference
  - Lower anterior facial height (ANS-Me)
  - Mandibular plane angle
  - Facial axis angle
  - Pogonion-N perpendicular
- **Advantages:** Integrates vertical plane analysis with sagittal; evaluates airway

### Ricketts Analysis (1969)
- Computerized analysis system
- **Key parameters:**
  - Facial axis (85.7°)
  - Facial depth (88.6°)
  - Mandibular plane angle (27.4°)
  - Convexity of point A (4.1 mm)
  - L1 to A-Pog (incisor inclination)
  - Lower lip to E-plane (aesthetic line)
- **Unique feature:** Forecasts treatment results and growth patterns
- **Five original measurements:** Facial angle, XY axis angle, contour measure, upper and lower incisor position to APo plane

### Other Standard Methods
- Downs analysis
- Sassouni analysis
- Jefferson analysis
- Ricketts analysis

---

## 4. FACIAL PROPORTIONS IN SIDE PROFILE MEASUREMENT

Professional side profile analysis uses specific proportional guidelines:

### Vertical Proportions (Thirds)
- **Upper third:** Hairline to Glabella
- **Middle third:** Glabella to Subnasale
- **Lower third:** Subnasale to Menton
  - Further subdivided: Upper lip (1/3) to lower lip and chin (2/3)

### Horizontal Proportions (Fifths)
- Each eye: 1/5 width
- Inner eye space: 1/5
- Nasal base width: 1/5
- Each outer temple: 1/5

### Angular Measurements for Profile
- **Maxillofacial angle:** Relationship between maxilla and mandible
- **Nasomaxillary angle:** Nasal and maxillary relationship
- **Nasal angle:** Tip projection
- **Mandibular angle:** Lower jaw contour
- **Z-angle:** Critical for lower face profile (normal ~80°)
- **Profile line:** Upper lip tangent to line; lower lip tangent or slightly behind

### Facial Types
- **Convex profile:** Indicates Class II skeletal relationship
- **Straight profile:** Indicates Class I skeletal relationship
- **Concave profile:** Indicates Class III skeletal relationship

### Soft Tissue Profile Analysis
- **Nasolabial angle:** Formed by nose base tangent and upper lip tangent
  - Normal range varies by ethnicity
  - Caucasian normal: ~102-110°
  - Affected by orthodontic extraction treatment
- **Profile evaluation includes:** Nasal projection, lip position, chin prominence, and overall facial convexity

---

## 5. COMMERCIAL CEPHALOMETRIC ANALYSIS TOOLS

### Web-Based Solutions (Cloud-Native)

**CephX** (cephx.com)
- AI-powered automatic landmark detection
- Processes lateral cephalograms or 3D volumes
- Provides instant tracing and analysis in seconds
- Supports 200+ custom analysis options
- Over 300,000 cases processed, 15+ years in operation
- FDA/MDR certified options

**WeDoCeph** (wedoceph.com)
- AI automatic tracing of landmarks, planes, arcs
- Soft and hard tissue silhouette detection
- Results delivered to repository in seconds
- Supports popular analysis types

**Ceph Assistant** (cephassistant.com)
- Advanced online software
- Supports profile photo, frontal photo, and cephalometric analyses
- Steiner, Ricketts, McNamara, Hasund, Eastman, ABO analysis options
- Won Vodafone Digital Award 2022 (Digital Society category)

**Cephio** (cephio.com)
- AI-powered cephalometric X-ray analyzer
- Automatic tracing and landmark positioning
- Steiner, Jefferson, Bjork analysis options
- PDF report generation

**WebCeph** (webceph.com)
- AI-driven orthodontic and orthognathic platform
- Automatic cephalometric tracing
- Visual treatment simulation
- Automatic superimposition
- Image archive and photo gallery

**AudaxCeph** (audaxceph.com)
- Detects 70-100 soft and hard tissue landmarks
- 200+ analysis types available
- FDA 510(k) cleared and MDR certified
- Works on lateral and PA cephalograms

**EasyCeph** (easyceph.com)
- No software purchase or annual fees
- Web-based analysis system

### Maxillofacial Surgery Planning (3D)

**PROPLAN CMF™ (Materialise)**
- Generates 2D/3D visualizations
- Covers orthognathic procedures, mandible/midface reconstructions
- Soft tissue simulation for post-operative prediction
- 3D cephalometric analysis
- Splint and anatomical model design/export

**VSP Craniomaxillofacial (3D Systems)**
- Virtual surgical planning for orthognathic procedures
- Real-time 3D bony movement and cephalometric analysis
- Occlusal data integration from high-resolution scans
- 3D printing tool generation (guides, splints)

**Planmeca Romexis® CMF Surgery**
- Advanced orthognathic software
- Anatomic landmark and measurement tracking
- Intermediate and final splint generation
- 3D cephalometric analysis integration

**Materialise Mimics Enlight CMF**
- Imaging segmentation system
- Visualization, measurement, design tools
- Realistic surgical outcome forecasting

---

## 6. AUTOMATED DETECTION TECHNOLOGY

### Deep Learning Approaches (2024)

The field has rapidly advanced with CNN-based architectures achieving clinical-level accuracy:

**Key Methods:**
- **Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN):** Primary approach, achieving >95% detection rate in recent studies
- **Mask R-CNN:** Achieving >98% detection rate with acceptable error margins
- **Multi-stage architectures:** Coarse-to-fine refinement for improved precision
- **3D CNN methods:** For CBCT/3D volumetric data
- **Transformer-based models:** Point cloud processing for 3D dental/facial geometry
- **Multi-modal fusion:** Combining lateral cephalograms, CBCT volumes, and dental models

### Performance Metrics

State-of-the-art systems achieve:
- **Mean Radial Error (MRE):** <2.0 mm (clinically acceptable threshold)
- **Success Detection Rate (SDR):** >90% within 2-3 mm range
- **Processing time:** Seconds (vs. minutes for manual tracing)
- **Accuracy:** Within 0.5 mm for analysis values in CNN-trained systems

### Notable Research Systems

**CEPHMark-Net (2024)**
- Two-stage regression framework
- Multi-head CNN architecture
- Landmark detection + refinement modules
- Published in Expert Systems with Applications

**Multi-Scale 3D CNN (2024)**
- Coarse-to-fine landmark detection
- Average RMSE: 2.238 mm
- Uses clinical dataset of 150 CT scans with 30 landmarks

**DeepFuse Framework**
- Multi-modal integration (cephalograms, CBCT, dental models)
- Attention-guided feature fusion
- Simultaneous landmark detection and treatment outcome prediction

---

## 7. PUBLICLY AVAILABLE DATASETS FOR RESEARCH

### Recent Benchmarks (2023-2025)

**Aariz Dataset** (Published July 2025 in Nature Scientific Data)
- **1,000 lateral cephalometric radiographs**
- Data from **7 different imaging devices** (most diverse dataset)
- **29 cephalometric landmarks** annotated by clinical experts
- Includes **Cervical Vertebral Maturation (CVM) stage classification**
- Creative Commons Attribution (CC-BY) licensed
- GitHub: https://github.com/manwaarkhd/aariz-cephalometric-dataset
- Best method achieved: MRE 1.789 ± 6.548 mm

**CL-Detection 2023 Dataset** (MICCAI Challenge)
- **600 lateral X-ray images**
- **38 landmarks** per image
- Multi-center, multi-vendor data
- Sources: ISBI challenge (400), PKU dataset (102), Shenzhen (92)
- Website: https://cl-detection2023.grand-challenge.org/
- Best methods: 75.719% detection rate, 1.518 mm error

**CephAdoAdu Dataset**
- Adolescent and adult cases
- Training: 400, Validation: 300, Test: 300 images
- Addresses age-related landmark detection variations
- GitHub: https://github.com/ShanghaiTech-IMPACT/CeLDA/

**Historical Benchmarks:**
- IEEE ISBI 2015: 400 cephalograms, 19 landmarks
- IEEE ISBI 2014: 300 cephalograms
- CEPHA29 (ISBI 2023): 1,000 images, 29 landmarks, 29 participating teams

---

## 8. KEY INSIGHTS FOR SIDE PROFILE IMPLEMENTATION

### Challenges in Automated Detection

1. **Overlapping structures:** Poor contrast and overlapping craniofacial anatomy in 2D X-rays
2. **Occlusion:** Dental braces, implants, and lead shields obscure landmarks
3. **Bilateral structure collapse:** 3D structures compressed to 2D radiographs
4. **Landmark variability:** Certain landmarks (orbitale, porion) inherently unreliable
5. **Inter-observer variation:** Manual annotation has significant variability

### Professional Workflow Insights

1. **Reference plane establishment** is critical before landmark detection
2. **Multiple analysis systems** are used together for comprehensive assessment (not just one)
3. **Soft tissue simulation** is now standard in surgical planning
4. **Growth prediction** factored into treatment planning
5. **Ethnicity, age, and gender norms** must be considered for interpretation
6. **3D imaging (CBCT)** increasingly supplementing 2D radiographs

### Practical Considerations for Web-Based Tools

- Cloud-based systems becoming industry standard due to:
  - Instant results (seconds vs. manual hours)
  - Consistency across operators
  - Regulatory compliance (FDA/MDR)
  - Integration with digital workflows
  - Cost efficiency at scale

- Typical workflow: Upload image → AI processes → Generate measurements/analysis → PDF report/export

---

## 9. REFERENCES

### Core Cephalometric Knowledge
- [Orthodontics, Cephalometric Analysis - StatPearls - NCBI Bookshelf](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK594272/)
- [Cephalometric analysis - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cephalometric_analysis)
- [A Beginners Guide to Lateral Cephalometric Radiographs](https://www.dentalprotection.org/uk/articles/a-beginners-guide-to-lateral-cephalometric-radiographs)

### AI/ML and Automation
- [Accuracy of cephalometric landmark detection from lateral facial photographs using CNN-based algorithm | Scientific Reports (2024)](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-024-82230-z)

## SUMMARY FOR YOUR PROJECT

Based on this research, here are key insights for your LOOKSMAXX side profile landmark detection:

1. **Established landmarks to target:** Nasion, Sella, Pogonion, Menton, Gonion, Subnasale, and soft tissue landmarks are universally recognized

2. **Frankfort Horizontal as reference:** Using Porion and Orbitale to establish a reference plane is industry-standard

3. **Multiple analysis systems exist:** Steiner, McNamara, and Ricketts are the "Big 3" - consider which one aligns with your goals

4. **Modern approach:** Web-based, AI-assisted landmark detection with multi-stage refinement is now the professional standard

5. **Soft tissue landmarks critical:** Professional tools emphasize soft tissue (nasal, lip, chin contour) in addition to hard tissue points

6. **Cloud-native tools winning:** Commercial solutions (CephX, WeDoCeph, etc.) are replacing desktop software due to speed and consistency

7. **3D not just 2D:** Moving from lateral cephalograms to 3D CBCT/volumetric analysis is the industry trend

8. **Open datasets available:** The Aariz and CL-Detection datasets provide benchmarks for training and validation
